title: Laughing stock of Team Trump
text:
Share on Twitter 
FROM the moment he entered the White House, Sean Spicer became an online sensation. 
The Press Secretary’s gaffes and confusing conferences have made him a source of mockery on social media — and it’s hard to combat the argument he brings it on himself. 
The most recent upset came when Mr Spicer was questioned over whether or not Mr Trump’s controversial policy to prohibit immigrants from seven Muslim-majority countries constituted a “ban”. 
Mr Trump himself used the term “ban” in a tweet he posted two days ago about “bad dudes” rushing into the United States: If the ban were announced with a one week notice, the "bad" would rush into our country during that week. A lot of bad "dudes" out there! — Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump) January 30, 2017 
Mr Spicer’s subsequent exchange with reporters at a press conference was cringeworthy. 
“So (Trump) says it’s a ban,” NBC News White House correspondent Kristen Welker put to Mr Spicer. 
“He’s using the words that the media is using,” Mr Spicer responded. 
“It’s his words!” fired back a reporter in the room. 
Mr Spicer said the order “can’t be a ban” if people are still being allowed into the country, instead referring to it as “extreme vetting”. 
OK, so, according to the Press Secretary, Mr Trump’s policy is not a “ban”, and the term “ban” is a concoction of the media. 
Let’s look at Mr Trump’s own tweet again: If the ban were announced with a one week notice, the "bad" would rush into our country during that week. A lot of bad "dudes" out there! — Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump) January 30, 2017 
Once more, with feeling! It seems pretty clear Mr Trump called it a ban. Source: Twitter b-a-n. Source: Twitter 
Welker didn’t let up. “The President himself called it a ban,” she persisted. 
“I understand,” said Mr Spicer. 
Welker asked, “Is he confused, or are you confused?” 
“No, I’m not confused,” replied Mr Spicer. “I think that the words being used to describe it are derived from what the media is calling this. (Trump) has been very clear that it is extreme vetting. 
“With all due respect, I think you have been part of the confusion.” 
Righto. 
THE INAUGURATION NUMBERS DEBACLE 
Mr Spicer was ridiculed immediately after Mr Trump’s presidential inauguration last month, after photos surfaced showing large swathes of empty space compared to Barack Obama’s inauguration eight years ago . 
He used his first press conference to blast the journalists in front of him for “deliberately false reporting” on crowd size. 
“This was the largest audience to ever witness an inauguration, period!” Mr Spicer said. 
“These attempts to lessen the enthusiasm of the inauguration are shameful and wrong. Photographs of the inaugural proceedings were intentionally framed in a way, one particular tweet minimised the enormous support that had gathered on the National Mall.” Mr Spicer used his first press conference to blast reporters over the size of Mr Trump’s inauguration. Source: AFP 
After blasting the reporters, he went on to blame “floor coverings” for the perceived smaller crowd at Mr Trump’s inauguration. 
“This was the first time in our nation’s history that floor coverings were used to protect the grass. That had the effect of highlighting areas where people are not standing, while in years past, the grass eliminated this visual.” 
He then promptly left the briefing without taking questions. 
An estimated 1.8 million people flooded the National Mall area in 2009 when Barack Obama was first sworn in as president, according to federal and local agencies at the time. 
Washington authorities reported a crowd somewhere over 720,000 people — less than half of the 2009 crowd. 
DEFENDING “ALTERNATIVE FACTS” 
On the weekend of Mr Trump’s inauguration, his senior adviser Kellyanne Conway was widely ridiculed after telling NBC’S “Meet The Press” that Mr Spicer “gave alternative facts” to the media narrative about the audience size. Kellyanne Conway was widely panned for using the phrase “alternative facts”. Source: AFP 
In an interview with Fox News’ Sean Hannity that Tuesday, Mr Spicer defended the widely-panned phrase, comparing it to different weather reports. 
“The press was trying to make it seem like we were ignoring the facts when the facts are that sometimes ... you look at a situation ... in the same way you can look at a weather report,” Mr Spicer said. 
“One weather report comes out and says it’s going to be cloudy and the next one says there’s going to be light rain. No one lied to you.” 
He then continued with his claim that Mr Trump had the largest inauguration turnout in history. 
RETWEETING “THE ONION” 
Earlier this week, Mr Spicer was made into a laughing stock after he retweeted a story about himself from well-known satirical site The Onion. 
The spoof article was a clear piss-take, with The Onion tweeting: “@SeanSpicer’s role in the Trump administration will be to provide the American public with robust and clearly articulated misinformation.” 
The clip included a list of five mocking “facts” about Mr Spicer, calling his speaking style “defensive” and asking whether he had knowingly lied to the press. 
“One’s own mental activity is the only unquestionable fact of one’s experience,” the video says. 
But Mr Spicer retweeted it regardless, writing: “You nailed it. Period!” You nailed it. Period! https://t.co/AUmS1C222b — Sean Spicer (@seanspicer) January 29, 2017 
Many questioned whether Mr Spicer was actually aware The Onion is a satirical site. *whispers* did @seanspicer realize @TheOnion is a satirical website or is he being sarcastic...why is the press secretary so bad at twitter
